text: Increased <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Protein Expression Is Associated with Low HTLV-I Proviral Load

text: Since <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is expressed almost exclusively within <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + <extra_id_0> CD25 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells , a major viral reservoir for HTLV-I [ 33 ] , it was important to determine whether there was an association between <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and HTLV-I replication in infected patients .

We therefore quantitated the <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein expression in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + <extra_id_0> CD25 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells by flow cytometry and the HTLV-I proviral load ( a surrogate marker of viral replication ) by real-time PCR from eight patients with HAM / TSP and eight asymptomatic carriers ( ACs ) .
The data from this analysis is summarized in Table 1 .

As expected , patients with HAM / TSP exhibited significantly higher proviral loads ( indicated as HTLV-I proviral DNA copies / 100 cells ) ( 34.68 +/- 23.19 ) compared to ACs ( 4.75 +/- 5.47 ) ( p = 0.0008 ) .

The percentage of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + cells within the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + <extra_id_0> CD25 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cell population was significantly greater in ACs ( 43.23 +/- 12.95 ) than in HAM / TSP patients ( 18.59 +/- 5.77 ) ( p = 0.0033 ) .
These data suggest that high levels of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein expression are associated with reduced HTLV-I replication in vivo .

text: They also support our recent reports that high proviral loads , which have been shown to correlate with high <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA in HTLV-I-infected patients , are associated with reduced <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression [ 8 , 34 ] .
